description:
Agrococcus versicolor is a species of bacteria that belongs to the genus Agrococcus. It is a Gram-positive, non-spore-forming, and non-motile coccus-shaped bacterium. Agrococcus versicolor was first isolated from soil samples collected in Thailand.

The cells of Agrococcus versicolor are typically spherical in shape, with a diameter ranging from 0.8 to 1.2 μm. They often occur in pairs or irregular clusters. The colony morphology on agar plates is described as circular, convex, and pigmented, ranging from yellow to orange in color.

Agrococcus versicolor is classified as an aerobic bacterium, meaning it requires oxygen for growth and metabolism. It is able to grow at temperatures ranging from 10°C to 37°C, with an optimal growth temperature around 28°C to 30°C.

Biochemically, Agrococcus versicolor is able to hydrolyze starch and casein, and it can reduce nitrate to nitrite. The bacterium is also known to produce carotenoid pigments, which contribute to its distinctive coloration.

The identification and characterization of Agrococcus versicolor provide insights into the diversity and distribution of bacteria in soil environments, particularly in tropical regions, and may have potential applications in various fields, such as bioremediation or biotechnology.
